author: Peter Dominiczak
title: Police asked to look into Tom Watson's role in sex case 'witch hunt'
text:
Tom Watson Police asked to look into Tom Watson’s role in sex case 'witch hunt’ A Tory MP calls on police to investigate whether Mr Watson wasted police time by making allegations about Lord Brittan Tom Watson, Labour’s deputy leader Photo: Rii Schroer By Peter Dominiczak , Political Editor 11:23PM BST 23 Oct 2015 Follow 
Tom Waton is facing calls for police to investigate his role in the decision to question Leon Brittan over an historic rape allegation. 
David Morris, a Conservative MP, wrote yesterday to Sir Bernard Hogan-Howe, the Metropolitan Police Commissioner, asking him to investigate whether Mr Watson wasted police time by making allegations about Lord Brittan, who died in January. 
The senior detective in charge of the investigation this week told MPs that the Met’s decision to question Lord Brittan, who was terminally ill at the time, was “unlawful” and amounted to a “baseless witch hunt”. 
Leon Brittan Photo: Alamy 
Det Chief Insp Paul Settle was dropped from the case by Scotland Yard after Mr Watson complained to the Director of Public Prosecutions. "I wish to report my suspicion that Mr Watson has wasted police time in doing what he has done. I should be grateful if that be investigated" David Morris, a Conservative MP 
Mr Morris is now calling for the Met to investigate Mr Watson after he “intervened to bring about two investigations by the police into an accusation of rape which were later closed due to lack of evidence”. 
Mr Morris is also calling for Kathryn Hudson, the Commons standards commissioner, to reconsider her decision that there was not enough evidence to open an inquiry into Mr Watson. 
Kathryn Hudson 
In his letter to the Met Police Commissioner, Mr Morris writes: “I wish to report my suspicion that Mr Watson has wasted police time in doing what he has done. I should be grateful if that be investigated. 
• Tom Watson pressured CPS to reopen second sex abuse case 
“I would also like to be made aware of the amount of hours of police time and public funds that were spent on investigating Lord Brittan following Tom Watson’s letter to the Director of Public Prosecutions.” 
Mr Watson has said that it was his “duty” to notify the Director of Public Prosecutions about allegations made against Lord Brittan.
